title: Lys Gracieux storms home to win the $5million Cox Plate in Melbourne
text:
Lys Gracieux has won the Cox Plate in Melbourne after charging through on the home straight to win the $5million prize.

The Japanese runner stormed home to win ahead of rivals Castelveccio and Kiwi import Te Akau Shark.

The short-priced favourite gained the advantage with 100m to go to succeed Winx - who had won the race four years in a row - as the latest Cox Plate title holder.

Lys Gracieux (pictured during trackwork session last week) has won the Cox Plate in Melbourne after charging through on the home straight to win the $5million prize

The racehorse's victory comes after Japanese stallion Mer de Glace streaked away to win the Caulfield Cup last week.

Like its compatriot, the mare came into the meet in fine form having won its last race overseas and placing third before that.

Jockey Damian Lane said it was a dream come true to race Lys Gracieux to victory.

The Japanese runner (pictured in the foreground ridden by jockey Damian Lane) stormed home to win ahead of rivals Castelveccio and Kiwi import Te Akau Shark

'Growing up as a racing fan watching my idols win this race, to now be on the honour roll is such a privilege,' Lane said

'Growing up as a racing fan watching my idols win this race, to now be on the honour roll is such a privilege,' he said.

'The pace was a lot stronger than I thought into the first corner and I just rode her back. She probably didn't ride that well but she was too good anyway.'

He added Lys Gracieux felt even more dominant on Saturday than she did in her last victory in her home country.

'She might have improved again which she has done through her older years which is remarkable,' Lane said.

Tasmanian runner Magic Wand saw its run at the title extinguished in the final moments after leading at one point on the back straight.
description: Lys Gracieux ran home strongly to take out the Cox Plate, overrunning three-year-old Sydney colt Castelvecchio, with New Zealand gelding Te Akau Shark running third.
authors: Charlie Coë For Daily Mail Australia
